shapiq_student package¶

Submodules¶

shapiq_student.basic_knn_explainer module¶

KNNExplainer module.

This module provides an exact KNN-based Shapley explainer that attributes predictions to individual training instances using exhaustive Shapley value computations.

This approach follows Jia et al. (2019) and calculates marginal contributions of each training point by evaluating all possible permutations of the training set.

class shapiq_student.basic_knn_explainer.KNNExplainer(model, data, labels, class_index=None, K=None)[source]¶

Bases: Explainer

Exact KNN-based Shapley explainer using exhaustive permutations.

This class explains the prediction for a given test instance by computing exact Shapley values for each training point using a k-nearest neighbors classifier.

For each permutation of the training set, the marginal contribution of each instance is computed by observing its effect on the prediction when added to a subset of preceding instances.

Parameters:

  • model (KNeighborsClassifier) – A fitted sklearn KNeighborsClassifier instance.

  • data (np.ndarray) – Training data as a 2D numpy array of shape (n_samples, n_features).

  • labels (np.ndarray) – Labels corresponding to the training data.

  • class_index (int | None) – (Optional) Class index to explain. If None, the predicted class is used.

  • K (int | None) – (Optional) Number of neighbors to consider. Defaults to the model’s setting.

Raises:

  • TypeError – If model is not an instance of KNeighborsClassifier.

  • ValueError – If data and labels have inconsistent lengths.

explain(x)[source]¶

Returns averaged Shapley values for one or more test points.

If multiple test points are provided, their individual Shapley values are averaged to provide a stable overall attribution.

Parameters:

x (ndarray) – A 1D or 2D array of test points to explain.

Returns:

An object containing the Shapley values per training instance.

Return type:

InteractionValues

shapiq_student.gaussian_imputer module¶

GaussianImputer module.

This module provides an imputer that fills in missing features by sampling from their conditional distribution, assuming the data is multivariate normal.

This approach follows Aas et al. (2021), which showed that conditional Gaussian distributions can be used to impute missing values in a principled way.

class shapiq_student.gaussian_imputer.GaussianImputer(model, data, x=None, sample_size=100, random_state=None, *, verbose=False)[source]¶

Bases: Imputer

Imputes missing features assuming a conditional multivariate normal distribution.

This class extends the base Imputer and uses background data to fill in missing values for features in a data point. It assumes that the data follows a multivariate normal distribution. It works by conditioning on the known features and sampling the unknown ones accordingly.

Parameters:

  • model (object) – A predictive model used to generate output values.

  • data (np.ndarray) – Background/reference data as a 2D array (n_samples, n_features).

  • x (np.ndarray | None) – The specific data point to explain, potentially with missing values.

  • sample_size (int) – Number of samples to draw for estimation (default: 100).

  • random_state (int | None) – Random seed for reproducibility (default: None).

  • verbose (bool) – If True, prints additional information during processing (default: False).

Notes

  • Handles “empty” coalitions (all features unknown) using a pre-defined empty prediction.

  • Supports “full” coalitions where no target variables remain.

fit(x)[source]¶

Fits the imputer to a specific data point x.

Stores the data point to be explained and rests any previous conditioning information.

Parameters:

x (ndarray) – The data point to explain.

Returns:

The fitted imputer instance.

Return type:

self

sample_conditional_gaussian(data, cond_idx, cond_values, n_samples=1, random_state=None)[source]¶

Samples from the conditional multivariate normal distribution.

Computes the conditional mean and covariance given known features, then draws samples for the unknown features accordingly.

Parameters:

  • data (ndarray) – Background data as a 2D array.

  • cond_idx (ndarray) – Indices of the known (conditional) features.

  • cond_values (ndarray) – The known feature values for conditional features.

  • n_samples (int) – Number of samples to draw (default: 1).

  • random_state (int | None) – Seed for reproducibility (default: None).

Returns:

  • conditional_samples (np.ndarray): Samples from the conditional distribution.

  • mu_cond (np.ndarray): Conditional mean vector.

  • sigma_cond (np.ndarray): Conditional covariance matrix.

Return type:

tuple

Notes

  • Uses the formulas from Aas et al.(2021), Equation (10) and (11) for conditional Gaussian distributions.

shapiq_student.subset_finding module¶

Module for finding the maximum and minimum coalitions of an InteractionValues object using brute force, greedy, beam search, and recursive search algorithms.

shapiq_student.subset_finding.beam_search_coalition(interaction_values, coalition_size, *, beam_width=100, maximize=True)[source]¶

Beam Search for best coalition of coalition size.

Parameters:

  • coalition_size (int)

  • beam_width (int)

  • maximize (bool)

Return type:

set[int]

shapiq_student.subset_finding.brute_force(Interaction_values, max_size)[source]¶

Brute force method for the minimum and maximum coalitions of size l. Used for having the correct output for testing. :param Interaction_values: The Interaction_Values object from which the minimum and maximum coalition are to be determined. :param max_size: The maximum length of the coalition to be found.

Returns:

Tuple of the InteractionValues object of the minimum and maximum coalition.

Parameters:

  • Interaction_values (InteractionValues)

  • max_size (int)

Return type:

tuple[InteractionValues, InteractionValues]

shapiq_student.subset_finding.recursive_greedy_coalition_max(Interaction_values, max_size, path, checked)[source]¶

Function to find the maximum value coalition using recursive greedy search. :param Interaction_values: The Interaction_Values object from which the maximum coalition is to be determined :param max_size: The maximum length of the coalition to be found :param path: The current path of the coalition being explored :param checked: The set of already checked coalitions to avoid duplicates

Returns:

A tuple containing the maximum value of any checked coalition and a list containing the indices of said coalition

Parameters:

  • Interaction_values (InteractionValues)

  • max_size (int)

  • path (list[int])

  • checked (set[frozenset])

Return type:

tuple[float, set[int]]

Returns:

A tuple containing the minimum value of any checked coalition and a list containing the indices of said coalition

shapiq_student.threshold_knn_shapley_explainer module¶

shapiq_student.weighted_knn_explainer module¶

KNNExplainer module (weighted variant).

This module implements an exact Shapley value explainer for training instances based on a distance-weighted k-nearest neighbors classifier.

This approach follows Wang et al. (2024), using full permutation enumeration to compute the marginal contribution of each training point.

class shapiq_student.weighted_knn_explainer.KNNExplainer(model, data, labels, class_index=None, K=None)[source]¶

Bases: Explainer

Exact weighted KNN-based Shapley explainer.

This explainer computes Shapley values for training instances by using a distance-weighted k-nearest neighbors classifier. For each permutation of the training data, it measures the marginal contribution of each training point to the prediction for a test instance.

Parameters:

  • model (KNeighborsClassifier) – A fitted sklearn KNeighborsClassifier with weights=”distance”.

  • data (np.ndarray) – The training data as a 2D numpy array.

  • labels (np.ndarray) – Class labels for each training point.

  • class_index (int | None) – Optional. The class index to explain. If None, the predicted class is used.

  • K (int | None) – Optional. The number of neighbors to use (defaults to the model’s setting).

explain(x)[source]¶

Computes Shapley values for a single test instance.

This method wraps the internal exact Shapley computation and returns the results in the standardized InteractionValues format.

Parameters:

x (ndarray) – A 1D or 2D numpy array representing one or more test points.

Returns:

Shapley values for the training instances.

Return type:

InteractionValues

class shapiq_student.GaussianImputer(model, data, x=None, sample_size=100, random_state=None, *, verbose=False)[source]¶

Bases: Imputer

Imputes missing features assuming a conditional multivariate normal distribution.

This class extends the base Imputer and uses background data to fill in missing values for features in a data point. It assumes that the data follows a multivariate normal distribution. It works by conditioning on the known features and sampling the unknown ones accordingly.

Parameters:

  • model (object) – A predictive model used to generate output values.

  • data (np.ndarray) – Background/reference data as a 2D array (n_samples, n_features).

  • x (np.ndarray | None) – The specific data point to explain, potentially with missing values.

  • sample_size (int) – Number of samples to draw for estimation (default: 100).

  • random_state (int | None) – Random seed for reproducibility (default: None).

  • verbose (bool) – If True, prints additional information during processing (default: False).

Notes

  • Handles “empty” coalitions (all features unknown) using a pre-defined empty prediction.

  • Supports “full” coalitions where no target variables remain.

Stores the data point to be explained and rests any previous conditioning information.

x (ndarray) – The data point to explain.

The fitted imputer instance.

sample_conditional_gaussian(data, cond_idx, cond_values, n_samples=1, random_state=None)[source]¶

Samples from the conditional multivariate normal distribution.

Computes the conditional mean and covariance given known features, then draws samples for the unknown features accordingly.

Parameters:

  • data (ndarray) – Background data as a 2D array.

  • cond_idx (ndarray) – Indices of the known (conditional) features.

  • cond_values (ndarray) – The known feature values for conditional features.

  • n_samples (int) – Number of samples to draw (default: 1).

  • random_state (int | None) – Seed for reproducibility (default: None).

Returns:

  • conditional_samples (np.ndarray): Samples from the conditional distribution.

  • mu_cond (np.ndarray): Conditional mean vector.

  • sigma_cond (np.ndarray): Conditional covariance matrix.

Return type:

tuple

Notes

  • Uses the formulas from Aas et al.(2021), Equation (10) and (11) for conditional Gaussian distributions.
